BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 12, 1923
THE LITERARY JOURNAL
The literary journal habit has become an annual pastime, so it
seems, from the frequent appearances on our campus of aesthetic
periodicals. Again we are forced to give a bit of free publicity to
these efforts.
There is at present much discussion as to the recognition of an
Delt::
other "purely literary" magazine. Omicron Delta Kappa, Pi
Epsilon and the various activities have passed resolutions opposinp
the publication.
There are several reasons why the magazine should not appea.
on this campus. The first of these is that there is not enough demand

BASKETBALL
It is most unfortunate, in more ways than one, that varsity- basketball is an impossibility at Johns Hopkins. Practically every college
in the state has a team engaged in the winter season sport. Yet our
University more favorably located than any of the others, cannot
find a place where it can be made a paying sport.
That splendid stage of pep, in which the football season leaves
the fan, is permitted to die down until the spring sports begin simply
because the sportlover has no outlet for his enthusiasm. Swimming
is on the schedule, it is true, but that type of sport does not excite
the enthusiasm that the team-play sport does.
The idea now being entertained by the interfraternity board, as
to conducting an interfraternity basketball league is an excellent one
if it may be found possible. Interfraternity baseball was a decided success last spring and there is no reason why basketball should not do
as well.
At such times that out-of-door practice becomes impossible, public schools may be used, if obtainable. School No. 51 is within five
blocks of the University and we have been informed than it has an
excellent court which the interfraternity board should be able to
secure upon application to the proper authorities.
tion enough competition.
In order to bar no one, the non-fraternity men might form a
quintet and enter the race. There is much talent on the campus; a
varsity quint could be formed that could give any team in this secIf the interfraternity league experiment proves a success, varsity
basketball may become a possibility. This looks like a real opportunity to give it a start.

IT was a cynic who said:"Some men go to
college, Other men study."
A slander! But yet there probably are college
men whose bills for midnight oil are not large.
And there are men who left school in the
lower grades who, along with a hard day's work,
put in long hours of study -spurred on by a
dream and a longing.
Look out for them.
The achievements of non-college men in business suggest an important fact. Success seems to
depend, not so much on the place where a man
studies, as on the earnestness of the student.
But, granting equal earnestness and ability, it is
still true that the college man has the advantage.
Regular hours for study and lecture, the use of
library and laboratory, the guidance of professors,
contact with men of the same age and aspirations
-all these will count in his favor, ifhe makes the
most of them.
A big "if." The new year is a good time to
start making it a reality.

THE LITERARY JOURNAL
The literary journal habit has become an annual pastime, so it
seems, from the frequent appearances on our campus of aesthetic
periodicals. Again we are forced to give a bit of free publicity to
these efforts.

BASKETBALL
It is most unfortunate, in more ways than one, that varsity- basketball is an impossibility at Johns Hopkins. Practically every college
in the state has a team engaged in the winter season sport. Yet our
University more favorably located than any of the others, cannot
find a place where it can be made a paying sport.
That splendid stage of pep, in which the football season leaves
the fan, is permitted to die down until the spring sports begin simply
because the sportlover has no outlet for his enthusiasm. Swimming
is on the schedule, it is true, but that type of sport does not excite
the enthusiasm that the team-play sport does.
The idea now being entertained by the interfraternity board, as
to conducting an interfraternity basketball league is an excellent one
if it may be found possible. Interfraternity baseball was a decided success last spring and there is no reason why basketball should not do
as well.
At such times that out-of-door practice becomes impossible, public schools may be used, if obtainable. School No. 51 is within five
blocks of the University and we have been informed than it has an
excellent court which the interfraternity board should be able to
secure upon application to the proper authorities.
tion enough competition.
In order to bar no one, the non-fraternity men might form a
quintet and enter the race. There is much talent on the campus; a
varsity quint could be formed that could give any team in this secIf the interfraternity league experiment proves a success, varsity
basketball may become a possibility. This looks like a real opportunity to give it a start.

IT was a cynic who said:"Some men go to
college, Other men study."
A slander! But yet there probably are college
men whose bills for midnight oil are not large.
And there are men who left school in the
lower grades who, along with a hard day's work,
put in long hours of study -spurred on by a
dream and a longing.
Look out for them.
The achievements of non-college men in business suggest an important fact. Success seems to
depend, not so much on the place where a man
studies, as on the earnestness of the student.
But, granting equal earnestness and ability, it is
still true that the college man has the advantage.
Regular hours for study and lecture, the use of
library and laboratory, the guidance of professors,
contact with men of the same age and aspirations
-all these will count in his favor, ifhe makes the
most of them.
A big "if." The new year is a good time to
start making it a reality.
